												Good game, it's not the best of balanced TD game out there, as some traps are OP as hell (Swinging Mace) compared to others that are just pathetic (Steam Trap), but balance is good enough that it will let you beat stages in many different creative ways so not everything has to be so cookie cutter and boring.Now for some advice time for the new players who for some reason is reading this crap on my profile... any-who, your upgrade priorities should be Tar Trap, Barricade, Swinging Mace, and Archer Guardians, those are the GOD level tier of traps and bread and butter to everything.Other notable traps are your Brimstone, Floor Scorcher, Spike Trap, Spring Trap, Arrow Wall, and Grinder, these here are your second level of tier stuff so start upgrading them when you can.The rest of your traps can go suck it because they do in fact all suck. Good luck on beating some of my high scores :P

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Orcs Must Die is a drama of apocalyptic dimensions. You’ll run around killing them with a mixture of clever traps and third person shooting but this tower defense game is really the story of the poor Orcs that you decimate. Every Orc’s story is told with a hallucinatory intensity, whether they were tossed off a cliff by a spring, slowed by tar before being perforated by poison arrows, burned to a crisp by ground based fire traps, or stabbed to death by the merciless protagonist. Orcs may not be real, but their trials and tribulations have taught me more about the fragility and splendor that we call life.I can’t express how transformative this masterpiece is. Let’s be clear, it’s not just a masterpiece of the tower defense genre, but of humanity itself.  Orcs must die has turned me into a better person. As a result of this game I’ve decided to clean up my act. I will no longer leave spike traps on the floor lest my future offspring trigger them. Also, I will try being friendly with strangers rather than freezing and shattering them.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2011
												Wow this game is addicting! Part shooter, part tower defense, this game is AMAZING! Not to mention hilarious! The point of the game is to defend Rifts, and to do this you must place traps on the floors, use magic, and your trusty crossbow. But the funny part comes with the way you can defeat the opposing Orcs. One way is to place Spring Boards on the floor that launch the orcs whereever you aim the board. This can result in humorous and deadly outcomes. Another example is the dialogue, just plain goofy! Plus....drum roll please....ACHIEVEMENTS!!! Yup another game with achievements to keep the gamer coming back for more slightly-stoopid bragging rights! Pick this game up! Its unique, funny, fun, and OMG FUN!!!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I liked Dungeon Defenders a lot, but Orcs Must Die is even better. There is just something so incredibly satisfying to watch hordes of Orcs get blended in a maze of traps. From spikes on the ground or the walls, massive popup furnaces that churn walls of fire, milling barrels, rotating axes and the most epic weapon of them all in my opinion, the swinging mace. Or if you want to have some fun, the spring trap that makes them go airborn. You can either make them fly over the halls from one side to another using spring traps that face each other (it's just funny to do that :D ) or you simply throw them in lava or acid. Don't feel like blending the orcs? No problem, you can shoot them yourself with crossbow or use various other powers on them as well as place archers and knights that will fight for you. And when you think you exploited all the options, there are also powerup cards that give you special abilities like stronger player characteristics, stronger and faster traps or more powerful weapons. You invest some of the funds you have to buy traps into them and make yourself or the traps more efficient. Just awesome blend of FPS, lite RPG and tower defense. It's brilliant and i can't wait to play Orcs Must Die 2. Just have 3 more missions in the first game, but so far i'm totally in love with this game. Oh and unlike in the Dungeon Defenders, you can re-route their paths with barriers, so you can funnel them through one hallway to make your defending job easier, create a choking point where they all clutter together. It gives the game a proper tower defense feel and a lot more options to exploit on for maximum Orc blending power!The game engine is also fantastic. From what i can tell they are using their own engine, but it's super fast, looks really good and has really nice character physics (really love the way how player's dress is affected by the movement) as well as physics that affect the orcs. And they achieved all this without the stupid PhysX. Thumbs up for that! And all this packed with quite well placed humor and player character making fun of himself and the orcs. And the way how developers presented the main character as the most stupid person in the world. It's just really funny game as a whole and love it for that.And since there are so many different options to play through the maps with various approaches to horde control you can have countless hours of fun with the game. Highly recommended as i guarantee you countless hours of insane fun!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												It took me cce 8 hours to complete first run on standard (not low) difficulty. Game offers variety of traps to serve one's "style" - are you a direct damage dealer, tricky tactician, do you like traps to do all the work or do you like being engaged in a fight? These and many more options are offered. The variety of monsters, their stregnth, number in comparison with your abilities, traps and magic is well balanced. There are points in game where player must be very flexible. When you finish game, you can start with all upgrades and traps unlocked from previous run and do campaign from scratch. There are tougher monsters coming in already at start. This is sad, because I would welcome ability to play new game already on highest. I am not going to play again. Not because I wouldnt enjoy it, but because I have no time and want to finish other games, too. In short - great chillout game.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												It's tough to talk about this after having played 2, but here goes.I enjoyed this game enough when I first played it.  Some of the later levels get tough, and there are really only a few viable traps/weapon combos, but it works out.  There isn't a lot that I would say is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, which is more than I can say for 2, but there also isn't much challenge, either.  Nightmare mode isn't necessarily hard, it just removes the strategy part of the game.  You're not given time to think/analyze/change placements, really.  I mean, yeah, that's hard, but it's also not really upping the difficulty in anyway.  Of course, maybe that's the best way to increase difficulty in a strategy game: removing much chance to strategize.There is, believe it or not, a story to this game.  I wasn't really aware of it for a while, but it's totally there and you might miss it if you're not paying attention.One quip I have is that things get redundant quickly, but whatcha gon' do.It's an alright game, good even, if a little stale/boring/dry at times.  Like I've indicated elsewhere, though, Two is an improvement in every way, from the interface to map design.  The addition of co-op was a much needed boost to OMD as well.If you skip this one you're not necessarily missing much.  A lot of the traps/dialogue/maps are carried over into two.  Still, this was an alright game.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Orcs Must Die! is a mix of tower defense and a third person "shooter".Singleplayer onlyGraphics:     5/10The textures are quite simple. I know the game was intended to look like a cartoon, but if the developers added a few more details and colors, the game would look much better. Visually I like most of the enemies, but some of them have a truly awful design. For example: The animations of the dragon-like, winged "things" (enemies) fluttering in the air are far too static and the textures are not more than mediocre. The particle effects are very fitting for the game. The traps are well made, but in my opinion the look of the "Shock Zapper" trap doesn't fit its function. I suppose that's a matter of taste though. The details of the map are quite low, but this provides a certain overview that the game needs in order to keep the building site highly visible. I rate the graphics of the game as moderate.Sounds:     8/10They really did a good job here. The background music fits perfectly and enhances the game's quality a lot. The trap sounds are amusing and adequate. The only thing I really miss are enemy sounds. Yes, there are enemy sounds, but you will hear them quite rarely. With the orcs being silent you can't really tell when they appear behind you. It may not be that important because the developers added a minimap, but that's a missed opportunity to make the game a little bit better.Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     9/10Both killing orcs with your weapon and with the traps is a lot of fun. The developers offer you a nice arsenal to protect the magical rifts. Spike traps, shocker, mushrooms, floor scorchers, archers and much more will help you slaying the orcs. The only thing what I really miss are really interesting weapons besides the crossbow and the alchemist bombs. The controls are easy to handle and building traps is no trouble at all.Level design:     5/10On the one hand the developers built some well structured tower defense maps (which isn't that hard I guess), on the other hand they really missed to add more details. You have the same wall and floor colors in almost every level. I would say you could rebuild those levels in minecraft with a good texture pack and it would look almost the same.Enemies/AI:     4/10The AI is - what a surprise - really poor. But I honestly didn't expect a complex AI from a tower defense game. So I will skip the rating for the AI and take a closer look at the enemy diversity. Besides the normal orcs there are big tough ogres, fast little kobolds, fast gnolls and flying creatures. The game doesn't actually need more enemies, but why did they just recycle the enemies and put a "frost-" "fire-" and "armored-" prefix to avoid designing more creatures?This kind of recycling is not necessary. 4/10.Story:     3/10Yes, it actually has a story. I was surprised. The hero is a sorcerer's apprentice who is now in charge of protecting the magic rifts (teleporters to the world) from the orcs because his master is dead who protected the magic rifts before. It's not quite a story, but a reason to fight against the orcs. I think I will give 3 points for the good attempt and the humor.Critic summary:     5.5/10Personal fun rating:     7/10     [good game]Well. It's a funny little game. No big title, but worth 5 bucks.I finished the game and I don't regret it.If you like tower defense games this might be an option.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												When I was young, I played a lot of tower defence games in Warcraft 3. But Orcs must die sets a new level in this genre.Combining a 3rd person action game with tower defence, it created the ultimate action survival game.Set in a fictional fantasy universe, you have to defend humanity against hordes of orcs from another dimension. For that, they built big fortress' around the portals, you have to defend.For that, you not only have weapons and spells, but a big arsenal of traps and mechanical defend systems, from ordinary spike traps to big swinging clubs, burning pits and big brutal mechanical grinders.Every level is made of one or several floors with one or several directions the enemys can spawn. You have to defend the rifts to the normal world, so the orcs dont conquer it.Using the right collection of traps, wisly using your abilitys and being a tactical genius desides about victory and defeat. The game doesnt take you lightly. With the first levels being easily understandable and mostly fast to solve, some maps are difficult beyond everything encountered before. Some maps need tricks you have to find out all by yourself, some just need you to be fast like sonic, defending two rifts at once.Having a small storyline, mostly living from comedy, the campaign is really fun to play. After one playthrough you unlock another difficulty, that is a serious challenge (and was a real pain for me).It isnt a real game for casual players, but a good game, for tacticans, that not only want to think but slay their way through their enemys.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2011
												A variation of tower defense where you have to place traps to defend cores from invading monsters. While there's lots of toys (with new ones being thrown at you every level), some get left in the dust/unused (boom barrel, steam trap), while others get progressively more broken as the game goes on (archers, paladins, decoys). My biggest complaint is it's missing the stat tracking most tower defenses have to help you maximize your gold usage,  leaving you to guesswork if your traps are laid out properly. The maps are uniquely constructed, often requiring specific tactics to clear effectively, making each map tense and engaging. About a third of your arsenal are weapons for your character which keeps you in the action most of the time, unlike most games in this genre.With 24 maps you're looking at a sizable tower defense game with plenty of crossbow-twitching, fireball-slinging, ice-shattering orc carnage.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												It's tough to talk about this after having played 2, but here goes.I enjoyed this game enough when I first played it.  Some of the later levels get tough, and there are really only a few viable traps/weapon combos, but it works out.  There isn't a lot that I would say is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, which is more than I can say for 2, but there also isn't much challenge, either.  Nightmare mode isn't necessarily hard, it just removes the strategy part of the game.  You're not given time to think/analyze/change placements, really.  I mean, yeah, that's hard, but it's also not really upping the difficulty in anyway.  Of course, maybe that's the best way to increase difficulty in a strategy game: removing much chance to strategize.There is, believe it or not, a story to this game.  I wasn't really aware of it for a while, but it's totally there and you might miss it if you're not paying attention.One quip I have is that things get redundant quickly, but whatcha gon' do.It's an alright game, good even, if a little stale/boring/dry at times.  Like I've indicated elsewhere, though, Two is an improvement in every way, from the interface to map design.  The addition of co-op was a much needed boost to OMD as well.If you skip this one you're not necessarily missing much.  A lot of the traps/dialogue/maps are carried over into two.  Still, this was an alright game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												This review was written after I beat the game.Fun and reasonably challenging. The dialogue, voice acting, and story, though sparse, are pretty funny, too. Each level is really a puzzle to be solved - there's not necesarilly a "correct" solution for how to place your traps, but there's "aha" moments when you discover a feature of the level that makes a certain setup very effective. The fact that you get to control a hero makes the gameplay much more fun - you can have a big impact on the enemy waves with skilled shooting and use of the various magic spells.There's plenty of replayability in competing on the leaderboards or among your friends for a high score.My one major complaint is that several of the levels have a split design where you can't force all of the enemies through one choke point, so you have to split up your attention between them or set up lots of traps and hope they're working well enough. It's kind of annoying to mentally deal with this and spend time running back and forth. I understand the point of the game is to be mentally challenging, but this task is more mentally exhausting than it is fun.I also don't like that you aren't told in advance exactly what enemies will be coming through which doors before each round. If you want to go for really good scores, it's just an unnecesarry and un-fun memorization tax upon you to remember each wave.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Orcs Must Die! is a mix of tower defense and a third person "shooter".Singleplayer onlyGraphics:     5/10The textures are quite simple. I know the game was intended to look like a cartoon, but if the developers added a few more details and colors, the game would look much better. Visually I like most of the enemies, but some of them have a truly awful design. For example: The animations of the dragon-like, winged "things" (enemies) fluttering in the air are far too static and the textures are not more than mediocre. The particle effects are very fitting for the game. The traps are well made, but in my opinion the look of the "Shock Zapper" trap doesn't fit its function. I suppose that's a matter of taste though. The details of the map are quite low, but this provides a certain overview that the game needs in order to keep the building site highly visible. I rate the graphics of the game as moderate.Sounds:     8/10They really did a good job here. The background music fits perfectly and enhances the game's quality a lot. The trap sounds are amusing and adequate. The only thing I really miss are enemy sounds. Yes, there are enemy sounds, but you will hear them quite rarely. With the orcs being silent you can't really tell when they appear behind you. It may not be that important because the developers added a minimap, but that's a missed opportunity to make the game a little bit better.Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     9/10Both killing orcs with your weapon and with the traps is a lot of fun. The developers offer you a nice arsenal to protect the magical rifts. Spike traps, shocker, mushrooms, floor scorchers, archers and much more will help you slaying the orcs. The only thing what I really miss are really interesting weapons besides the crossbow and the alchemist bombs. The controls are easy to handle and building traps is no trouble at all.Level design:     5/10On the one hand the developers built some well structured tower defense maps (which isn't that hard I guess), on the other hand they really missed to add more details. You have the same wall and floor colors in almost every level. I would say you could rebuild those levels in minecraft with a good texture pack and it would look almost the same.Enemies/AI:     4/10The AI is - what a surprise - really poor. But I honestly didn't expect a complex AI from a tower defense game. So I will skip the rating for the AI and take a closer look at the enemy diversity. Besides the normal orcs there are big tough ogres, fast little kobolds, fast gnolls and flying creatures. The game doesn't actually need more enemies, but why did they just recycle the enemies and put a "frost-" "fire-" and "armored-" prefix to avoid designing more creatures?This kind of recycling is not necessary. 4/10.Story:     3/10Yes, it actually has a story. I was surprised. The hero is a sorcerer's apprentice who is now in charge of protecting the magic rifts (teleporters to the world) from the orcs because his master is dead who protected the magic rifts before. It's not quite a story, but a reason to fight against the orcs. I think I will give 3 points for the good attempt and the humor.Critic summary:     5.5/10Personal fun rating:     7/10     [good game]Well. It's a funny little game. No big title, but worth 5 bucks.I finished the game and I don't regret it.If you like tower defense games this might be an option.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Fun fact: I dislike Tower Defense games for being boring, repetitive and unpersonal. Oh, and boring, just to mention it again.Another fun fact: Orcs Must Die is NOT a tower defense game, even though it could easily be mistaken for one. But I would rather consider it a 'Tactical Defense TPS'. You're not a commander building towers, you're a guy building traps which are meant to aid you in wrecking Orcs. Lots of them. And boy, it's fun.Let's begin with the art style and sound. Both are fluent, coherent and quite fine. I won't say superb, because the game obviously is neither an AAA title nor top-actual, but it's well above what would be necessary as a minimum.A big point of the game is it's humor, that clearly hit my favour. Whether it's Orc's philosophing and quoting famous memes, or the utterly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-charming protagonist, or his even more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ monologues, the game makes you chuckle. Whilst orc's get gibbed left and right.Which is literally all this game is about: Killing orcs in the most fashionable/efficient/hilarious way possible. You got a wide array of different traps, weapons and champions at your disposal, and often the level'S themselves have special environmental hazards, high bridges ideal to kick orcs off from, lava pits...Even as an enemy of TDGs, the game was great to play.Which leads us to it'S only downside: 'was'. The game is terribly short. I've beaten the entire campaign + bonus missions at this point, with a perfect completion on about 75% of all levels (many of those on first try). Yes, there is a 'Nightmare' difficulty, but I'm not sure whether I will go for that or rather switch to the sequel ofthis game instead.But hey, it's a budget game,so we can't exspect 40h playtime, can we?Result: 8/10 Solid and extremely satisfying way to waste time. ^^

content:
Posted: October 15, 2011
												Wow, the tower defense titles these days actually improve on what is already a fun game genre. In Orcs Must Die you control a warmage, in third person view. So instead of building traps in an isometric sort of  view, you now run around setting up traps and actively killing enemies with your character. There's never a dull moment and the fact that you gain new traps after finishing a level gives incentive to keep playing. You'll want to come back for more, it's THAT fun.Other than that, the game mechanics are pretty much the same as any other tower defense game; you kill enemies, earn cash, upgrade traps, and try to prevent enemies from taking over your rifts.Only downside, in my opinion, is that it's a single-player affair. I'm sure it would've been more fun when played in co-op mode but maybe that's something for the sequel.Don't let that stop you from buying it though ![Rating: 87/100]

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Orcs Must Die is easily my favorite downloadable title for 2011. Why? Because it takes classic tower defense and makes something new, innovative, and fun out of it. The game blends third person action with tower defense strategy creating a very unique experience. The game is very well designed on that regard, meaning that it is impossible to beat a level using only traps or only spells (you must use both). You play as a War Mage able to use spells and weapons to stop the Orcs from entering the Rift. You also have the ability to lay traps throughout the environment. Each trap is uniquely designed and offers different gameplay elements. Some examples of traps are tar traps to slow enemies, swinging maces, spike traps, arrow wall traps, etc. You play a good amount of levels progressing through a very simple but entertaining storyline. Overall, Orcs Must Die offers a very new and unique experience for Tower Defense fans. To put it simply, if you like tower defense, GET THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2011
												Orcs Must Die! is an orc racism simulation. You play as a white guy, the apprentice of another white guy, and spend literally the entire game killing orcs. That's super racist! I mean, it's not like it's sort of racist or anything like that. The name of the game is "Orcs Must Die!" It's not "Orcs Must Die if Convicted of a Capital Crime" or "Orcs Must Die if it is Necessary to Employ Lethal Force in the Course of Self Defense" or "Orcs Must Die if they are Soldiers in a Justly Fought War" or anything like that. Replace "Orcs" with any other race in the title and you'd have a lawsuit on your hands! The only reason this game isn't banned in Germany is because nobody cares about orcs. I give this game 13 out of 16 race riots.

Do you like shooting orcs in the face?If you answered yes to any of these questions, then get Orcs Must Die!, and trust me you'll have a blast. It's challenging, fun and the dialouge is funny. Worth it all the way.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												I am not a fan of tower defense games, but this game (and it's sequel) give a refreshing spin on the genre. It combines 3rd person shooter with tower defense. This allows you to actively participate in the defense. You'll be shooting down enemies while managing your defenses.The level design gives you enough choice to try out different tactics. Sometimes there is one obvious tactic. Other times you have to try out different combos. Even though not all traps are as powerful/balanced, you can't always use the same traps. This gives enough variation through out the game.Orcs Must Die 2 adds a few new features:+ Co-op+ Endless Mode+ New playable class (mage)+ More customization

												A unique twist of the Tower Defense genre of games using traps instead of towers and 3rd person action. You are encouraged to use a crazy mix of traps and spells to rack up ridiculous combos and kill streaks. With 24 Levels, plenty of trap, weapon and spells, 3 upgrade trees and a lot of orcs and other nasties to slay, for $14.99 you cannot go wrong with purchasing this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												It might be easy to dismiss OMD! as a FPS/tower defence variant reliant on its tongue-in-cheek humour and simple gameplay to appeal. While these are two of its key strengths, there is far more to OMD! however; it has very well designed levels, plenty of weapon choices and types of enamy, as well as many different potential styles of play. Nightmare difficulty (available after the campaign has been completed) requires particular dexterity and speed of thought and adds further longevity to the mix. All that said, the real reason this game is recommended by so many people is that killing the titular orcs is immensely good fun. Eviscerating an orc wondering whether its parking has been validated as its friend explodes a day before it is due for retirement (the back stories courtesy of the grumbles the orcs utter as they amble towards you) frankly never gets old. Having just completed Nightmare with over thirty thousand kills to my name, I can safely say I would happily sign up to melt, crush, shoot, detonate, squash, burn and generally mangle the little gits all over again. Given this was released in 2011 it comes on sale quite often and is definitely worth a go.

												With a title like that how is one supposed to refuse?  Ok it's actually rather fun.  For the seasoned tower defense expert it's a rather fun 3D variation.  Tower Defense for the uninitiated is at it's best a grid based puzzler.  Choose how and where to defend utilising resources you earn.  The more experianced you become, the more traps and defenses you can place.  It's biggest failing is that there is no autofire.  Constantly having to slam the mouse button to fire an arrow or whack a sword becomes a little tiring.  Would I reccommend it?  Yes I would on a steam sale, simply for the fun sounds and indie humour, dotted around endearing orcy goodness.  A quick level now and again, is what makes a solid indie hit.  Without the "just one more go" deliciousnous of games like this, we'd forget the simple pleasure of gaming.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												One of the most addictive and energetic games I have played lately is Orcs Must Die. At first I was somewhat alarmed by the fact of non-stop killing with the help of various mechanisms, but when I started to play it I was totally absorbed in the process. It can be classified as Tower Defense game, but among other rivals in this type of computer games it is IMHO one of the best.  The aim of Orcs Must Die is very simple – not to let hordes of orcs, trolls and the like into our world. You are given a tower with one or several portals to be defended from numerous waves of monsters. Upgrading from level to level you are also provided with new different devices, skills, mechanisms, as well as earning money to money to buy ambushes and modernize them. The two most brilliant features of the game are in my opinion the highest level of action tension (what I feared most while playing is that somebody of my household would call me for something) and the elements of tactics and strategy.read more http://www.viewforum.net/gaming-dept-171/orcs-must-die-2767/

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												A superb 'Tower Defense' game that will have you coming back for more. 


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Orcs Must Die' 

			Views: 15		

			You can get the game here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/102600 A non-biased quick look @ 'Orcs Must Die' - A superb 'Tower Defense' game that will have you coming back for more.		

Slice them, burn them, skewer them, and launch them - no matter how you get it done, orcs must die in this fantasy action-strategy game from Robot Entertainment. As a powerful War Mage with dozens of deadly weapons, spells, and traps at your fingertips, defend twenty-four fortresses from a rampaging mob of beastly enemies, including ogres, hellbats, and of course, a whole bunch of ugly orcs. Battle your enemies through a story-based campaign across multiple difficulty levels, including brutal Nightmare mode! Will you roast orcs in pits of lava, pound them flat with a ceiling trap, or freeze and shatter them with a slash? No matter the weapons and traps you choose, you’re sure to have an orc-killing blast!  - Highly Recommended!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												I think this game is a sin... yes a straight up  biblical sin; it's  far too fun to be anything but sinful, wrong or cancer causing. I'm serious. There is nothing I can find to dislike about this game. The graphics are crisp. even in the pitch melee you can always pick out high priority targets, the music is very nice for the background and the sounds ... on the slicing of metal and the funny wails of agony never sounded so good.It is also frustratingly difficult at times, don't be fooled by the early missions, it starts ramping up fast but it's a good challenge, the sort that has you reformulating your strategy when you lose and dancing when you win.There's also the humor... it is actually funny to listen to the voice overs at time, it sounds like something Blizzard would have done about 8 years back.. around the time of Warcraft 2/3...you know.. before they stopped making games and started designing payment portals..Give it a try, you won't regret it.  Defense with a twist. Now if you'll excuse me... I have a bridge to mine with catapult traps.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												I had difficulty getting into this, especially after having playing Orcs Must Die 2 co-op with a friend.  Many of the levels, it seems, require you to run back and forth between two different entrances.  In co-op this works marvelously (10 of the original maps can be played in the second title in the series), as each player can hold an entrance, calling the other when things get hairy.  The number of weapons and traps is also less than the second game.  Perhaps this is an unfair criticism, but at the very least, perhaps this review will be helpful to others who are tempted to visit the first game after trying the sequel.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2012
												OMD is an entertaining, furiously addictive mixture of 3rd person shooter and tower defense, with a splendid soundtrack that perfectly compliments the frantic action.   You play as the rather dense but ♥♥♥♥♥ure Warmage, who must defend the magical Rifts from untold numbers of marauding orcs, using an array of traps, guardians, spells and weapons.   The main game of achieving a 5-skull rating (no orcs escaping, within a par-time) on all maps is a good challenge - which further fuels your abilities at large-scale orc maiming, as skulls can then be spent to upgrade your equipment.   Slaying the hordes is plenty fun enough, however therein also lies a complex combo-system adding much further depth of play, where the more traps and their afflictions hit an orc, the higher the combo-points, thus making every map replayable to experiment and chase that higher score.   Crisp graphics, great voicing, music, humour and still packed with pure, fun gameplay that's as good on a pad as with a mouse.   Quality arcade action that's only surpassed by it's more content heavy sequel, yet still worth playing first.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Orcs Must Die is at its core a tower defense game, but in 3D, with a below average FPS element. If you are a fan of tower defense games, I'm sure you'll get a lot of enjoyment out of the game, since there is a lot of content.If you are a FPS gamer however, you'll probably get bored very quickly, as I did. Orcs Must Die was probably never intended to compare to "real" FPS games, and as such, the combat, difficulty, and enemy diversity and adaptation is lacking when you compare it.It's really annoying that you can only recommend a game, or not. If you are tower defense player, Orcs Must Die is amazing value. If you are an FPS gamer, Orcs Must Die is disappointing.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												It looks fun doesn't it? yeah thats what I thought too. But that was before I got it. The concept of being able to attack yourself and use towers is nice and when executed properly works well. Orcs Must Die did not execute it well. Its problem is that if you don't attack you fail and on most every map there are 2 points the orcs come from and there are not 2 of you so you kill 1 side while the other gets through then you go to push back the other side meanwhile the side you were protecting gets up and then your at the very end of the map trying to shoot 2 ways at 1 time and it doesn't work. The only tower to make your enemys stop (at least as far as I played) is not even a tower its a KILLABLE Paladin. So unless you make like 3 of those at each side they all die. Even with 3 they die. Even with lots of support from ranged towers they die. Without using them the enemys move too fast and your towers can't hit them for long enough to kill them and you die.Another big problem is that they tryed to make too many towers. You get a tower after each level and they were probably running out of ideas and were just making stupid things. What I really don't like is that 90% of the towers have almost no difference except look or wether its on the wall or the floor or the ceiling. And alot of them just push the orcs so they are only usefull in certain levels where they can push the orcs off the level. Also the ceiling mounted ones alot are useless because the level will have too high ceilings and they won't hit anything.It was fun for the first 8ish levels but overall I give it a 5/10. I would recommend you go buy Sanctum 2

content:
Posted: March 14, 2012
												While OMD is a very cute game, it suffers from some fairly crippling design flaws.  Firstly, most of the levels' difficulty results directly from one decision the devs made; instead of allowing choke-points or open spaces or a single path, the people who made this game decided that each level be bifurcated, but provided portals to allow us to traverse the two.  Pick one, devs.  Difficulty or ease.As well, barricades are among the most expensive single buildables.In this vein, it is much more economically viable to murder all the monsters yourself, as traps are A) very expensive and B) reset much too slowly.  So why, for the love of Atheismo, is there only a 'cash bonus to trap kills' purchaseable!?  Why can't we simply rely on weapons?  Oh, right-- because the devs decided to split each level in two, so we can't simply use one route or the other.  You're forced to use both the (mandatory) crossbow and (shoddy, unreliable) traps.Still, it's a fun romp, even for its faults and flaws.

												Tower Defense - CheckShooting Stuff/Third Person Action - CheckIf you like either of those, then you should like this game. Even if you dislike strategy games I feel like you'll like OMD! It's more of a "blood pounding, hope my arrow traps reset in time, must race with orcs to stop them from getting to the rift" than a monotonous "set trap here to kill this orc." I'd recommend it to anyone who likes killing stuff, shooting stuff, and just generally wreaking havoc with a swinging ball mace repeatedly killing orcs stuck in the tar pit below it.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												The game can easily be summed up by its title. Orcs Must Die is about making a large amount of orcs into a large amount of dead orcs (and orc pieces). Of course, there's more to it than simply "Use crossbow on orc" as there are a number of fiendish traps, magic, and AI guardians that you can employ, making it something akin to a tower-defence game. There's more focus on action, though, as you're encouraged to jump in and do your part in causing a bit of death and dismemberment of your own. On top of it all is a somewhat basic story, though there is so much character and humor packed in that it still seems fresh and entertaining. To call the game "mindless fun" would be a little misleading as there is some strategy involved in trap placement and personal upgrades, but the real fun lies in watching a group of clueless orcs wandering towards a corridor full of all manner of blades and spikes and being reduced to "orc salsa" while you giggle softly to yourself.

Posted: February 5, 2012
												There's so many positive things I can say about Orcs Must Die. It's a game which won't disappoint even the most hard to please gamer, as It's packed with so much fun, humour, and thought.Orcs Must Die is more or less the same as Plants vs Zombies. It's a game where you must place traps in order to stop the horde of enemies from reaching their goal, and every new level brings a new trap. With every new trap of course brings a new enemy, so be prepared for this when organising your traps.Aswell as traps you can also use magic, and choose upgrades through-out the various levels through a card system.Being as this is the first game from Robot Entertainment, I give this game a big 10/10. There isn't many people who won't enjoy this game. It's pretty hard to find weak points. There's few bugs, has good graphics, and overall perfect gameplay.Pick this awesome game up at any opportunity. You won't regret it.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												Orcs Must Die is a third person tower defence game. You play as the magicians apprentice and you must stop the Orcs from reaching the Rift, which is a portal to your universe.Each level the Orcs break through the doors (or fly through holes in the ceiling) and make their way to the Rift coming in waves. You lay traps in their path, from spiked floors to swinging blades the Orcs blunder through your traps becoming so much meat and with each death you get more money to place more traps. Of course should you get bored of watching them die you can enter the fray yourself firing either a rapid fire crossbow or engaging in melee. Once you complete the level you get skulls based on how well you did which you use to purchase and upgrade traps.This game is pretty good, if a little repetitive and the difficulty really ramps up in the later levels, especially if you haven't got the right traps or upgraded them enough. It's very satisfying to see a horde of Orcs be decimated as they wander through your traps, all the while never firing a single shot yourself.For £6.99 it's a great game, well worth the price.

Posted: December 7, 2011
												It's Lord of the Rings meets Sanctum in this brilliant action/tower defense game. From the moment you lay your first trap you will be drawn in by the distinctive characters. As the title implies there is only one objective, you must kill every last orc that charges into your keep. The myriad of traps at your disposal, as well as your keen sword and spells, get this task done with prejudice. It's wickedly entertaing and slightly demented watching the orcs hurl themselves into spinning blades and explosive barrels, all the while taunting you and laughing about their impending victory. I had childish glee when the hero started trash talking back. For a game with only one hero and a handful of enemy types it is dripping with charm and style. However it is not without minor issues. The animations could use a little more work and the single minded gameplay won't last forever, but these are barely worth mentioning. The dark sense of humor and the variety of death mark this as a must play8/10

Posted: July 15, 2014
Recommended 5/5!Orcs Must Die! is a really well made and optimised game. The graphics are adorable yet not too cartoony. The animations of the enemy and the main character are funny. Music and sounds fit perfectly into the game but after some battle, the same battle music might get boring. Even a "low-end" PC can play it well. The game mechanics are well engineered. You are controlling an apprentice Warmage. On every map, the enemy attacks in waves and you have to use Traps and spells to stop them. Don't judge in advance, its not a simply Tower Defense game. It is kinda complicated because you have some kind of a talent trees. 3 of them. This way, you can costumize your gameplay so its not the same every time (You can focus on traps, guardians or spells). There are 25 levels and 3 game difficulty. The Nightmare mode is really challenging and you will enjoy completing the game in Nightmare. Some achievements are hard to achieve but definitely doable. You have to finish the game in Nightmare mode. It took me 20 hours to get every achievement.Spoiler:There is a background story but nothing fancy. You are an apprentice Warmage as I said before. Your master died and every other Warmage is being killed by a mysterious enemy which will be revealed. Of course you save every castle and close every rift. You save the world but without the rifts, there are no magic left.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												The mechanics for this game are truly brilliant. Animation, interface, sounds, visuals, balancing of weapons...not a whole lot of thinking for the user, but enough to be satisfying. Kudos to the developers for creating something pleasing to both the thinking man and the non-thinking man, and every man in between.

Posted: July 14, 2012
												Orcs Must Die gets a place right there next to my beloved Defense Grid and Sanctum! This isn't marketed as a Tower Defense game, but any fans of the genre will love this professionally developed defense game. This game evenly balances the importance of you being in the fray, and being thoughtful about your traps. You choose (and upgrade) your loadout before going into battle, and the options are so well varied that you can approach things with a variety of different options. The overall "feel" of the game from combat mechanics to funny storyline are all exceptionally fun. Plus, like the great aforementioned games, this game leave plenty for you to improve upon and goals to pursue. Oh, and the difficulty curve is a great match to my tastes which is rare (gets genuinely difficult).

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Variety is what keeps this third-person tower defense game going. With the myriad scenarios and cartoonishly gruesome methods of dispatching orcs at your fingertips, it's hard to put down. My only gripe with Orcs Must Die! is that there doesn't appear to be any sort of multiplayer mode or level editor, things that would vastly increase the game's replayability. However, despite being a single player game it's very entertaining. Even after you beat it the surprisingly deep combo/scoring system will keep you coming back for more as you try to inch your way up the leaderboards.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Orcs Must Die! is an extremely fun Tower Defense game, with a very nice mix of tower (trap) defense and third person action game.While there are clearly some traps which are much more useful than others and you will tend to gravitate towards them, there is still a large amount to choose from, so you can easily set up some deadly combinations to defeat the invading orcs.The gameplay is where the game really shines, while the level design is so-so, the sheer amount of variety in the game compensates for that.The only major fault of the game is that it appears personal abilities are very strong and can overshadow the traps themselves, so if you are strategy minded you might be disappointed since, especially in the early waves, you will have to rely heavily on your character to do most of the work.Great game let down by balance issues and level design.8 / 10

Posted: December 28, 2011
												Ever played Trapt (PS2, 2005/6)? It's kinda like that except without as much charm, difficulty, atmosphere, synergy or interesting narrative.This game is another one of those innovative third-person shooter meets tower defence games that definitely have not been cropping up by the dozen lately, but don't let that out of the box thinking put you off of this title. As harsh as my opening line might have been, this isn't really a bad game. (Certain) Traps are interesting, the tone of the game is quite tongue-in-cheek and it's very easy to lose a lot of time while playing.Strangely this game puts more emphasis on the actual fighting yourself rather than tower defence mechanisms. Traps are expensive and nearly always fire off too early, catching only the first thing in range and letting the horde behind which through.Still, a fun little arcade title. Worth it in a sale.

If you enjoy tower defense or are a fan of Dungeon Defenders, this humorous game cranks up the difficulty accordingly as you go along and offers an abundance of towers and weapons to use. So, pick this up while it's still cheap!

But you start off with a few traps, and you must defend the "Rift" by killing orcs.If orcs start passing through the Rift, a "Rift Point" is taken off. You're weapons at the start of the game are the Crossbow and Sword. As you progress through the game, you unlock a series of traps and weapons to enhance your ability to kill orcs. And there will be more enemies. And harder enemies. So basically, in a way, you're never "stronger" than the orcs. Posted: November 29, 2011
												Ostensibly a Tower Defense game, Orcs Must Die is a downright fantastic take on the genre.  With an art style reminiscent of Torchlight and a light-hearted sense of humour revolving around all the myriad ways to kill Orcs, OMD is as fun to watch and listen to as it is to play. The game offers a lot of options, and it does a good job of making them all viable.  You can be just as effective using traps to decimate Orcs as you can be wading in with Crossbow and Bladestaff.  You can use traps to deal direct damage, or take advantage of physics and fling the Orcs around like ragdolls.  You can also opt to be a weapon-wielder, lopping heads and shooting faces, or you can load up with spells and lay all kinds of elemental smackdown.  Or any combination of the above.  Orcs Must Die is an aesthetically pleasing game that transcends its origins and does not disappoint in living up to its namesake.  This game is excellent.

You not only make traps, you also run around with a sword or gun or frost magic and fight as well. It's entirely possible to win the game without a single trap.  It's also entirely possible to win without a single sword swing but both would be incredible difficult. I loved wasting time on this game.

Posted: March 19, 2012
												Tower Defense done right. Well is it really tower defense? It's a yes and no. Towers in this case are traps and you can place them during waves as well if you have money. However you yourself can also defend (much like Sanctum, in fact these two are simliar in more ways then one). Some of the early levels you can beat without usinga  single trap but later you'd have a very hard if not impossible time (in my opinion) to beat the levels without using traps. Traps vary from simple floor spikes and wall arrows to flame spitting floor traps and tar pits. It's not your traditional tower defense but it fits enough for me to put it in this genre. Upgrades to the traps comes outside of the levels and are permanent. No need to worry about which one to upgrade, you do it once and it's for good. There are a lot of traps and weapons in this game, a great variety for many different strategys and plenty of replay value.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												A single player tower defense action game. As the name suggest your character must defend a room from an onslaught of orcs. The orcs will come through a door as their starting point. Each will proceed to the end goal at the opposite end (usually) of the room. You will run around setting up traps of all kind. Along floors, walls, and ceilings. Traps consist of lava, tar, spikes, and so on. Unlike alot of other defense games this game has more interaction. During and in between rounds you can purchase and lay your traps through out. However, you can also attack the oncoming orcs with one of two weapons. A melle and range weapon set this game apart. Being able to actively attack enemies makes this that much more fun. No need to feel as just a spectator to the game. Most enemies wont attack you as they are driven to their goal. However, as the levels proceed difficulty increases. With newer enemies comes new threats, and new threats begat new traps to counter. If strategy and defense is your cup of tea. I highly recommend this title as the ability to attack will bring something new that you will enjoy. However, if it is not your cup of tea. I still recommend it for the very same reason.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												A good combination of first person shooter and tower defense game with some low brow sarcastic humor.Pros:+ It is not an easy game on the higher difficulty levels and in later stages of the game.  You will have to know your traps, choose your traps wisely, and get good at quickly placing them.  Be prepared to lose often and a whole lot on the Nightmare difficulty.  However, I do feel like I earned the win after I have been getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me on levels that I have had trouble with.+ Sound effects, music, and the voice overs from the orcs are cute though a bit repetitive.  + Graphics and level design are nice to look at.  + While a single set of traps can get you through many levels, some levels have a design that occassionally forces you to rethink whatever strategy you have settled into.Cons:- When using the crossbow while the monsters are at point blank range, I often shoot through a monster.  Not sure if this is a bug or a feature to force you to use the melee weapon.- While there are a variety of trap types that are unlocked as you progress they seem to fall into categories of use that make them seem like "upgrades" of older traps instead of a new unique trap.  For example I found that I pretty muched replaced the Spike Trap with the Tar Trap and the Wall Grinder replaced the other wall traps when making my trap selections.- The Gnoll Hunter moves through barricades without breaking them first.  This might be a legit ability of that monster but with their speed and ability to poison it feels like this is less "increasing the difficulty" and more "cheating."- Some issues with the camera that I mostly notice when backing up against a wall that has a small alcove and when standing under the Swing Mace Trap.- Some of the spash screens that pop up while loading do have some scantily clad characters that could cause some awkwardness.

Posted: December 2, 2011
												Quite possibly the most underrated game of the year, this gem is filled with fine-tuned and "always fun" values that I never see anymore. It combines the best elements of effecient defense strategies with TPS/beat-em-up gameplay. The variety in different ways you can play each level gives it immense replay value. Only downside is that the first playthrough might be a bit easy for experienced players of either genre. Fortunately, there's a Hard Mode included that can appeal to you.Ever played tower defense games, and wished you were on the field to make up for the terrible micro happening before your eyes? This can put your abilities to the test if you use tactics that empower your own character instead of countless traps and guardians.There's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ demo, see the glory or yourself.

Posted: December 6, 2011
												Orcs Must Die! is a real gem of an indie game. It offers a creative take on the tower defense genre with plenty of options to approach each challenge. The mixture of strategy and action game elements coupled with tight controls flow together very well, leaving you with one very satisfying experience. The game also has a good sense of dark humor that, while it may get repetitive at some points, has yet to come across as annoying.All in all, I highly recommend this game. If you love the tower defense genre you shouldn't think twice about getting it. The game offers a great experience that is well worth the price and is still fun to play again and again.

Posted: February 13, 2012
												I have played relatively few Tower Defense games, it being a genre that does not generally appeal to me. Orcs Must Die essentially said to me, "Okay, so you don't like sitting around watching towers kill things. How about if YOU get to kill things too?" And I was like "Okay OMD, I'm listening." And what fun I had. Orcs Must Die strikes an amazing blend of frantic third-person combat with the strategy of Tower Defense, creating a game that forces you to think and react with equal speed. It is challenging, occasionally frustrating but ultimately very rewarding, not every game leaves me feeling so satisfied when the credits finally roll. It's damn funny too, with its idiotic but endearingly determined protagonist and an Ork horde that's quite disenchanted with the whole marauding business and would rather not die horrible deaths in the service of their whiny sorceress.

												I have to say that when i first heard of this title i thought it didnt sound much fun. but i have to say there is a great deal of joy when you just basically curbstomp some orcs with magic. its VERY polished and pleasing to look at. the sound effects and music are as if midevil musicians decided to play some form of hiphop. its definitly a game that is hard to put down. basically it just feels rewarding and the things you use to kill them vary widely, and they all have a nice look to them that fits well in its suroundings. though i am cheap i say wait for a sale. but if you really REALLY like tower defense games and a bit more polished version and a little bit more thrilling version of dungeon defenders, this is a title for you. as much as i would like there to be a multiplayer, it shows that they spent their time focusing on the game in place of a split focus of how to make multiplayer work and how to make the game look nice and better yet FEEL nice. it just has a great feel!

Posted: January 30, 2012
												I have never been the biggest fan of Tower Defense games. But after playing a good 7 hours of Orcs Must Die over the last 2 days, I can honestly say that this title gets a spot on my favorites list. Robot Entertainment has produced  a challengeing, trhrilling, laugh out loud chaotic little gem. Nothing quite equals the satisfying feeling of frantically rushing around, strategically lining the corridors of a fortress with implements of death, and then watching your assailants fall in droves under hails of arrows, floor spikes, wall blades, and brimstone tiles. The 3rd person over the shoulder camera puts you smack in the middle of the chaos, immediatley lending the game a sense of urgency you don't feel in other TDG's simply because your character's life is in peril because your character is THERE. Humor, depth, and white knuckled pacing set the tone for a well made, fun game that is worth picking up. (Especially at such a low price.)

Posted: September 15, 2015
												I absolutely love this game!It clearly did not have a huge budget. There are no super expensive intros and the graphics are rather simple (but effective and not bad in any way).But it is the concept that is so much fun. Building traps for the Orcs to run into and get killed in the most hillarious of ways is incredibly satisfying. The dialogue and voice acting are well done. The music fits the theme (but is a bit repetitive). The animation is great. The story is funny. The hero is likeable.My only critique would be that it is a bit short if you paid the full price. It feels like the game only just started when it is already over. You really want to make use of the last few types of traps more often before the game ends. And I never really got to ues the Weavers that much either (there never really is that much money). I wished there had been more levels to explore this upgrade mechanic and the last few traps a bit more. Because of its shortness, best wait until it is on sale. 8 out of 10

Posted: February 8, 2013
												9 out of 10.It took me about 12 hours to get through the 18 map campaign, and I've spent at least another 12 going back and replaying the levels to try to get more achievements and better level scores.  Each map probalby takes 10 minutes to play.  You run around setting up traps (kind of tower defense-like) to kill the orcs, kobolds and ogres as they try to make their way through the map from the gate to your rift.  You have weapons as spells for direct combat.  It's fun to see if you can build the best configuration of traps to stop all the monsters.  Single player only.  Very stable, I only noticed one very minor bug with a monster getting stuck in lava and not dieing, but I was able to work around it.  The character you play is very humorous in the things he says and does, as are the orcs.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												While steam says i currently have 0.2 hours recorded playing this, I own it on xbox 360 as well and Ive completed the game. Honestly this is one of my fav games of all time. Absolutely love it so I dedcided to be the first to share my thoughs and opinions. Now on to the review :) Its a hybrid third person action game with tower defense. this means all your descisions and actions play out all in real time so when your defending against those nasty orcs, timing and well thought out traps are crucial. Yor goal is to keep the orcs from reaching a certain point on the map called, the Rift.The Rift was built in a forsakened fortress to keep everyone safe but now the orcs want to get to it and destroy you if you get in their way. Your teacher fell in battle so now it's up to you, The apprentice to defend the rift! The story is not really what this game is about but you are greeted whith the occasional cut scene. The game starts off with only a few waves and the basic set of orcs which are fairly easy to kill, as long as you don't sit there and let them attack you....but who would do that right? Each level in the game has a set number waves, each increasingly more difficult. The good thing is you always know what you're up against and just how many Orcs your going to slaughter in that particular level. The Orcs also range from ground units to archers to flyers and big tanks that take alot of damage. Also, each orc has a weakness so exploiting it in your traps and strategy will help alot. While the onslaught of orcs never stops, you have plenty of weapons and traps at your disposal, which brings me to my next topic, The traps! Each trap has a set fuction and there are a number of them which can only be placed on walls, floors, ceilings etc. They range from your simple barricades to huge swinging ceiling axes, to decoys and meat grinders, to archers and guardians. You also have weapons to choose from to kill the orcs yourself, thats what i love about the game. Youre not just looking down and watching the fight, youre in it. So it is up to you to work with your traps and stop the orcs from reaching the Rift. Although, in later levels you must defend more than one rift at a time which means the game can get pretty tough.  The rift will heal you when your close enough so if your ever in a pinch, you can go back and refill your hp which is nice. The game also scores you on your accuracy and headshots and the amount of kills in a row. Depending on how well you do, your awarded with up to 5 skulls, these are your currency. However, you cannot move on to the next level(s) unless you have earned enough skulls in previuous levels. So doing well, is essential. Yes the game can get challenging fast and you can lower the dificulty, but that reduces the amout of skulls to be earned, so its sort of a trade off. With the skulls you can purchase new upgrades and traps as well as bonuses that effect you and your traps, later on in the game. Now again i will say have not played this on pc yet but on xbox, there were no problems as far as framrate and lag. So I would check the system specs before you go ahead and make the purchase, as with all games. The visuals are quite nice and really stand out compared to most other tower defenses. The art style is a little silly and cartoony but dont let that fool you. When your killing orcs or watching your traps bruttally tear them apart..the gore and sense of pain does make the game feel less childish. Controls felt great on my xbox game pad although I would imagine mouse and keyboard is slightly better, accuracy and speed do play a big role here. Now i will say the game may have some flaws but I personally think Its close to perfect. And Im sure OMD2 fixes any issues this one may have. Theres more to the game than I've mentioned but I wont spoil it all. Lets just say if you like tower defense games and third person shooters/action, you should deffinitely give this a go. Robot Entertainment's Orcs Must Die! gets a 5 out 5 edit: I mainly bought this to replay levels in OMD2, and yes i will be reviewing the sequal when I finish it!

Posted: December 24, 2011
												The nearly simultaneous release of this game and Dungeon Defenders has led to inevitable comparisons between the two games, and rightly so. Both games are Tower Defense games played on a personal level rather than a top down perspective. Both have the player control a character that can run the course of maps, place a number of defenses and traps, use different abilities and go toe to toe with the advancing mobs with melee and ranged weapons. The difference comes in the approach. Dungeon Defenders distributes the different abilities among different classes making the game virtually unplayable in single player especially if you’re playing a support class. Orcs Must Die has no multiplayer but gives all the abilities to one character with new abilities with each successful mission. Orcs Must Die also feels much more action oriented. If you’re looking for a good tower defense game that you can play by yourself, look no further than this game!

Posted: December 19, 2011
												Get it.  Seriously.  Although I like tower defense, I was on the fence about games that put you at the front of the action.  This one does more than convince me of this take on the genre - it keeps me coming back for more, time and again.  It's a simple game on the surface, offering an incredible amount of depth and replayability.  The story, though rather stark, is carried by a hilarious, well-acted lead (think a somewhat less intelligent Ash meets a less annoying and offensive Duke) and I genuinely wanted to know more about the world.  This is certainly a franchise I hope Robot Entertainment expands on in the future.  Go get it now and duke it out with me on the leaderboards!

												Rating: 4/5     "A very fun twist to tower defense."Orcs Must Die is a comical game, and a unique hybrid of Tower Defense and Platform.  You play as a Sorcerer's Apprentice, who inherits his Master's mission after his most unfortunate (and oddly hilarious) death.  At your disposal is your late Master's spellbook, which provides you with the means to summon traps, guardians, and magical weapons which can all be used to single-handedly combat an army of Orcs...and luckily so, because that's exactly what your mission entails! Orcs Must Die features a simple control system, engaging gameplay, an overconfident, narcissistic main character, and orcs...lots and lots of orcs! An overall great game for almost anyone's video game repertoire!

Posted: February 16, 2015
												A good combination of first person shooter and tower defense game with some low brow sarcastic humor.Pros:+ It is not an easy game on the higher difficulty levels and in later stages of the game.  You will have to know your traps, choose your traps wisely, and get good at quickly placing them.  Be prepared to lose often and a whole lot on the Nightmare difficulty.  However, I do feel like I earned the win after I have been getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me on levels that I have had trouble with.+ Sound effects, music, and the voice overs from the orcs are cute though a bit repetitive.  + Graphics and level design are nice to look at.  + While a single set of traps can get you through many levels, some levels have a design that occassionally forces you to rethink whatever strategy you have settled into.Cons:- When using the crossbow while the monsters are at point blank range, I often shoot through a monster.  Not sure if this is a bug or a feature to force you to use the melee weapon.- While there are a variety of trap types that are unlocked as you progress they seem to fall into categories of use that make them seem like "upgrades" of older traps instead of a new unique trap.  For example I found that I pretty muched replaced the Spike Trap with the Tar Trap and the Wall Grinder replaced the other wall traps when making my trap selections.- The Gnoll Hunter moves through barricades without breaking them first.  This might be a legit ability of that monster but with their speed and ability to poison it feels like this is less "increasing the difficulty" and more "cheating."- Some issues with the camera that I mostly notice when backing up against a wall that has a small alcove and when standing under the Swing Mace Trap.- Some of the spash screens that pop up while loading do have some scantily clad characters that could cause some awkwardness.

Posted: November 24, 2011
												Orcs Must Die is a dating simulator based on actual events, about a guy who lives in a castle and joins a shady online dating service. He then spends the rest of his life attempting to interview these would-be green suitors to find the love of his life. Sadly, his dates often rush the gates and fall victim to the castle's insanely jealous defense system. It's up to our fair prince to use his trusty Crossbow of Love and his Sword of Choosing to place that special touch on the suitors that meet his fancy, and who aren't grieviously injured by the castle.All in all, I found this to be a very tragic tale, as well as a cautious reminder of the horrors of online dating. It's also a really great game, even if you don't usually happen to like historical-based dating simulators.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												Orcs Must Die is a third person tower defence game. You play as the magicians apprentice and you must stop the Orcs from reaching the Rift, which is a portal to your universe.Each level the Orcs break through the doors (or fly through holes in the ceiling) and make their way to the Rift coming in waves. You lay traps in their path, from spiked floors to swinging blades the Orcs blunder through your traps becoming so much meat and with each death you get more money to place more traps. Of course should you get bored of watching them die you can enter the fray yourself firing either a rapid fire crossbow or engaging in melee. Once you complete the level you get skulls based on how well you did which you use to purchase and upgrade traps.This game is pretty good, if a little repetitive and the difficulty really ramps up in the later levels, especially if you haven't got the right traps or upgraded them enough. It's very satisfying to see a horde of Orcs be decimated as they wander through your traps, all the while never firing a single shot yourself.For £6.99 it's a great game, well worth the price.

Posted: April 11, 2012
												This game is pure fun. It's always a frantic rush around the level picking off the few stragglers and strategically thinning the ranks with a crossbow or magic spell.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												While steam says i currently have 0.2 hours recorded playing this, I own it on xbox 360 as well and Ive completed the game. Honestly this is one of my fav games of all time. Absolutely love it so I dedcided to be the first to share my thoughs and opinions. Now on to the review :) Its a hybrid third person action game with tower defense. this means all your descisions and actions play out all in real time so when your defending against those nasty orcs, timing and well thought out traps are crucial. Yor goal is to keep the orcs from reaching a certain point on the map called, the Rift.The Rift was built in a forsakened fortress to keep everyone safe but now the orcs want to get to it and destroy you if you get in their way. Your teacher fell in battle so now it's up to you, The apprentice to defend the rift! The story is not really what this game is about but you are greeted whith the occasional cut scene. The game starts off with only a few waves and the basic set of orcs which are fairly easy to kill, as long as you don't sit there and let them attack you....but who would do that right? Each level in the game has a set number waves, each increasingly more difficult. The good thing is you always know what you're up against and just how many Orcs your going to slaughter in that particular level. The Orcs also range from ground units to archers to flyers and big tanks that take alot of damage. Also, each orc has a weakness so exploiting it in your traps and strategy will help alot. While the onslaught of orcs never stops, you have plenty of weapons and traps at your disposal, which brings me to my next topic, The traps! Each trap has a set fuction and there are a number of them which can only be placed on walls, floors, ceilings etc. They range from your simple barricades to huge swinging ceiling axes, to decoys and meat grinders, to archers and guardians. You also have weapons to choose from to kill the orcs yourself, thats what i love about the game. Youre not just looking down and watching the fight, youre in it. So it is up to you to work with your traps and stop the orcs from reaching the Rift. Although, in later levels you must defend more than one rift at a time which means the game can get pretty tough.  The rift will heal you when your close enough so if your ever in a pinch, you can go back and refill your hp which is nice. The game also scores you on your accuracy and headshots and the amount of kills in a row. Depending on how well you do, your awarded with up to 5 skulls, these are your currency. However, you cannot move on to the next level(s) unless you have earned enough skulls in previuous levels. So doing well, is essential. Yes the game can get challenging fast and you can lower the dificulty, but that reduces the amout of skulls to be earned, so its sort of a trade off. With the skulls you can purchase new upgrades and traps as well as bonuses that effect you and your traps, later on in the game. Now again i will say have not played this on pc yet but on xbox, there were no problems as far as framrate and lag. So I would check the system specs before you go ahead and make the purchase, as with all games. The visuals are quite nice and really stand out compared to most other tower defenses. The art style is a little silly and cartoony but dont let that fool you. When your killing orcs or watching your traps bruttally tear them apart..the gore and sense of pain does make the game feel less childish. Controls felt great on my xbox game pad although I would imagine mouse and keyboard is slightly better, accuracy and speed do play a big role here. Now i will say the game may have some flaws but I personally think Its close to perfect. And Im sure OMD2 fixes any issues this one may have. Theres more to the game than I've mentioned but I wont spoil it all. Lets just say if you like tower defense games and third person shooters/action, you should deffinitely give this a go. Robot Entertainment's Orcs Must Die! gets a 5 out 5 edit: I mainly bought this to replay levels in OMD2, and yes i will be reviewing the sequal when I finish it!

												There's so many positive things I can say about Orcs Must Die. It's a game which won't disappoint even the most hard to please gamer, as It's packed with so much fun, humour, and thought.Orcs Must Die is more or less the same as Plants vs Zombies. It's a game where you must place traps in order to stop the horde of enemies from reaching their goal, and every new level brings a new trap. With every new trap of course brings a new enemy, so be prepared for this when organising your traps.Aswell as traps you can also use magic, and choose upgrades through-out the various levels through a card system.Being as this is the first game from Robot Entertainment, I give this game a big 10/10. There isn't many people who won't enjoy this game. It's pretty hard to find weak points. There's few bugs, has good graphics, and overall perfect gameplay.Pick this awesome game up at any opportunity. You won't regret it.
