Posted: January 31, 2015
												This will be the first half of our review for the Orcs Must Die! series. This is the review for the first game, the overall score of which will be averaged with the overall score of Orcs Must Die! 2 to give us our final score for the series as a whole. So far, it’s prospects of a solid score are looking fantastic. Let us begin.I – Story [7/10]Orcs Must Die! is a third-person tower defense game from Robot Entertainment, in which, the player assumes the role of the Hero; an otherwise unnamed character and the last living member of the Order. The Order is an ancient and powerful guild of War Mages who have taken it upon themselves to guard Rifts (magical portals that connect the human world and the “Dead World” which also provide a source of magic throughout both worlds.)The Dead World is home to a faction known as “The Mob” and is comprised of various creatures such as gnolls, ogres, and (of course) orcs. The Mob is lead by a former student of the Order known as the Sorceress. During the course of the game, the Hero is fighting to keep the Mob at bay despite their every increasing aggression and frequency of attacks.Spoiler Alert: In the end, the Hero steps through a Rift and closes it forever by means of a spell. Although he saves the human world from destruction at the hands of the Sorceress and her limitless legions, he also destroys the source of magic for both worlds. The human world, now dependent upon magic, begins to steadily deteriorate. The Sorceress, stripped of her powers, is trapped in the Dead World with a gratuitous amount of angry monsters.The of OMD! should be thematically familiar to the vast majority of gamers, moviegoers, and readers alike. It is tried and true and it worked wonderfully for the game. That being said, it has still be done before.II – UI [9/10]The user interface was great. It was simple, the minimap worked like a charm, and I kept pressing the “ready” button long before I was actually ready. (Please note that that was not the game’s fault, it was all mine. It felt necessary to talk about it though.) In-game HUD was very user friendly and all of my stats/currently equipped traps (towers) and equipment were easy to refer to. However, the menus seemed to feel a bit clunky. Maybe it was just me, but I felt that they could have used a little tweaking.III – Gameplay [10/10]As I mentioned in a previous article, I wasn’t always a fan of tower defense games. In most cases, I’m still not crazy about them. But, every now and then, one comes along that attaches itself to my heart like a parasite and sticks with me for the long haul. Orcs Must Die! is one of those special little parasites.The vast majority of the maps are incredible free form as far as defensive strategies go. The game starts you off with fairly easy maps and they continually increase in complexity as you hack and slash your way through the campaign. As someone who is (in general) not very good with strategy, I weirdly loved this. It gave me a good chance to brush up on my defense skills and figure out what needs to be where so I’m not eyeball deep in orcs in a few minutes. Should I build outward or inward? Do I need to worry about aerial a-holes or not? Loved it.As far as using your character in combat, the third-person perspective was implemented expertly. A reticle is clearly displayed (and not easily lost) so that I can wade straight into the action if need be or snipe fools out from afar. Primary and secondary weapon functions are easily used and easily mastered. Movement is very fluid and the character’s sprint speed is comfortable fast.IV – Content [10/10]Orcs Must Die! has a lot of content, especially for a tower defense game. The core game has 24 maps, 6 weapons, 19 traps and minions (in total), and 11 different enemy types. Not only this, but any upgrades you purchase for weapons, traps, etc. are permanent and stay with you throughout the entire game. This is fantastic, in case you were wondering.There are two different DLCs for OMD! (Artifacts of Power and Lost Adventures) and both add their fair share of extra content as well. Really though, if you end up purchasing this game, you’ll probably end up picking up the DLC at some pint as well because you’re going to want more.V – Visual [10/10]Every last graphical detail of Orcs Must Die! is enchanting. Character and enemy models are very well done and have a charming, cartoon-esque quality to them. The environments are wonderful and every map has something new for you to ogle in your downtime. When you’re not setting traps or slaying orcs, it’s really worth it to take a few minutes to just explore your surroundings.VI – Audio [10/10]Seldom has a game had a more fitting soundtrack than Orcs Must Die! does. Seriously though, just phenomenal. You can annihilate thousands and tens of thousands to this epic score and never grow tired of it. That goes for the annihilation too. It has a very metal feel to it on the whole and I’m sure that War Mages the world over could happily crush skulls to it all day long.On top of the score, the voice acting is absolutely superb. The Hero is hilarious and you’ll find yourself laughing at his one-liners and his celebratory dance moves map after map.VII – Overall [9.3/10]Overall, Orcs Must Die! is a great game and a true testament of what a tower defense game should be, in my opinion.

Posted: November 27, 2011
												Orcs Must Die takes the tower defense formula and tweaks it just enough to be something a little different; there's greater emphasis on both traps and your own combat abilities rather than just towers, allowing you to become more involved in the action. Combating the invading orcs and either watching them run through your stabbing, slicing, or smashing traps or dicing them up with your bladestaff and puncturing them with your crossbow bolts rewards you with some entertaining gibs, and the quips from both your character and the green brutes is good for a few chuckles. If you're looking to kill a short time with one or two rounds or fill out a boring afternoon with several more, Orcs Must Die is definitely an entertaining diversion worth looking into.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This or Dungeon Defenders or Monday Night Combat or... well, approach the notion with this question: do I have ANY friends at all? If the echoing response happens to be a sheepish "...no..." then call Orcs Must Die your newest and only bud.Orcs Must Die shares more in common with the likes of Lock's Quest than any of the previously mentioned seige-style titles. You, as the Apprentice, are the sole line of defense for a series of interdimensional whatsits. Good, hands-on slaughter earns bonuses; creative execution of traps earn you multipliers. This set up should dispell for you where the focus of Orcs Must Die sits: action first, clever second.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												For me, more outright fun than Sanctum or Dungeon Defenders. Dungeon Defenders suffers from a Sisyphean feeling of level and item grinding common to MMO's, and Sanctum feels too prescriptive in what approach you need to take to win like more traditional tower defense games. Orcs Must Die avoids this rewarding you with a new toy on each level, and only requiring grinding to beat highscores. Gaining access to new combinations, and highscore tracking, keeps replaying earlier levels interesting.

Posted: December 13, 2011
												An excellent single player indie game.Has 3 game modes - warmage, nightmare and high scoring. Played within that order. Once you have completed the game on nightmare you can aim for the highscore tables, but high scores are achieved by getting combo kills, so require entirely different tactics. The traps are interesting, there are a handful that you will never use and others you will use in some levels. The swinging mace is one of the most deadly traps you can use.2 DLCs - Lost adventures adds 5 maps, 1 is a map already in the game played in reverse (a very unique map and a very entertaining map, playing in reverse does make it harder). They also added a handful of new monsters, like the frost bat. Well worth getting.               - the second DLC is not as worth while, contains a few new traps and weapons. Accessable from the start of the game as well, which makes the first few levels extremely easy if used. However, both DLCs are worthing picking up when on offer.

Fend of orcs in an epic onslought, using your wits and your crossbow to prevent them from entering the rifts. With lots of different traps, spells and a decent amound of enemy variety this game does one hell of a job in the third person TD genre. The game is not perfect though. The levels are all very gray and brown and as you are nearing the end of each lv, your defence has usually become so solid that there is no need for you to even be there. But if you can live with that (and I know I could), then this game sure is a hell of a lotta fun.

Posted: August 28, 2012
												Orcs Must Die! is a tower defence game that uses a third person action oriented perspective instead of the traditional top down view of similar games.Its a very fun and entertaining game that will last you around 11 hours depending on your playstyle. A constant progression of new weapons, traps and enemies drives you through the adventure, and ensure the same strategy won't work for every level. Not only do you lay traps as in a typical tower defence game, your character can also move around and contribute to the kills to complement the traps you have set. The graphics are bright and colourful and animations are very fluid. Music and sound are crisp and clear and the game is a joy to play.Downsides, this game is single-player only. Having a friend in multiplayer mode to help cover some of multiple enemy entrances would have made it an even more enjoyable experience.Overall Rating: 8.0 / 10Entertaining and fun game in a new twist on the tower defence genre. Don't miss it.

Posted: December 9, 2013
												Excellent tower defense game - simple and responsive controls, crisp graphics, fun storyline. A good mix of strategy and skill. The 'level grade' system and Nightmare difficulty add extra layers of replayability to the game, forcing you to adapt your strategies and use a wide range of skill and trap builds for different encounters, while simultaneously demanding better playskill from you in the form of aiming (ie. headshots can cause significantly more damage) and laying traps under pressure.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												A FPS tower defense that's actually fun to play. Unlike some of it's predecessors... *cough* Sanctum *cough*.The developers knew what their strengths were and focused on them. The result is a game that's enjoyable for what it is, without losing its way trying to be something it isn't.While it's relatively short - it'll only take a couple days to "beat" - there's plenty of replayability if you want to perfect your strategies or just enjoy shooting Orcs in the face.Even though I'd never pay $60 for a game like this, it's hard to go wrong with an MSRP of $15.Try the demo, you'll know right away if this game is for you.

Posted: November 29, 2011
												Ostensibly a Tower Defense game, Orcs Must Die is a downright fantastic take on the genre.  With an art style reminiscent of Torchlight and a light-hearted sense of humour revolving around all the myriad ways to kill Orcs, OMD is as fun to watch and listen to as it is to play. The game offers a lot of options, and it does a good job of making them all viable.  You can be just as effective using traps to decimate Orcs as you can be wading in with Crossbow and Bladestaff.  You can use traps to deal direct damage, or take advantage of physics and fling the Orcs around like ragdolls.  You can also opt to be a weapon-wielder, lopping heads and shooting faces, or you can load up with spells and lay all kinds of elemental smackdown.  Or any combination of the above.  Orcs Must Die is an aesthetically pleasing game that transcends its origins and does not disappoint in living up to its namesake.  This game is excellent.
